title: ~Towards a Complete View of the Certificate Ecosystem~
abstract: ~The HTTPS certificate ecosystem has been of great interest to the measurement and security communities. Without any ground truth

column10: we comparatively analyze all these perspectives. We find that aggregated CT logs and Censys snapshots have many properties that complement each other

title: ~DDoSCoin: Cryptocurrency with a Malicious Proof-of-Work~
column5: Bitcoin has used a hash-based proof-of-work to generate new blocks
column6: and create a single public ledger of transactions. The hash-based computational puzzle employed by Bitcoin is instrumental to its security
column7: preventing Sybil attacks and making double-spending attacks more difficult. However
column8: there have been concerns over the efficiency of this proof-of-work puzzle
column9: and alternative “useful” proofs have been proposed. In this paper
column11: which is a cryptocurrency with a malicious proof-of-work. DDoSCoin allows miners to prove that they have contributed to a distributed denial of service attack against specific target servers. This proof involves making a large number of TLS connections to a target server
column12: and using cryptographic responses to prove that a large number of connections has been made. Like proof-of-work puzzles

title: ~Imperfect Forward Secrecy: How Diffie Hellman Fails in Practice~
abstract: ~We investigate the security of Diffie-Hellman key exchange as used in popular Internet protocols and find it to be less secure than widely believed. First
column5: we present a novel flaw in TLS that allows a man-in-the-middle to downgrade connections to “export-grade” Diffie-Hellman. To carry out this attack
column6: we implement the number field sieve discrete log algorithm. After a week-long precomputation for a specified 512-bit group
column7: we can compute arbitrary discrete logs in this group in minutes. We find that 82% of vulnerable servers use a single 512-bit group
column8: allowing us to compromise connections to 7% of Alexa Top Million HTTPS sites. In response
column9: major browsers are being changed to reject short groups. We go on to consider Diffie-Hellman with 768- and 1024-bit groups. A small number of fixed or standardized groups are in use by millions of TLS
column11: and VPN servers. Performing precomputations on a few of these groups would allow a passive eavesdropper to decrypt a large fraction of Internet traffic. In the 1024-bit case
column12: we estimate that such computations are plausible given nation-state resources
column13: and a close reading of published NSA leaks shows that the agency’s attacks on VPNs are consistent with having achieved such a break. We conclude that moving to stronger key exchange methods should be a priority for the Internet community.~
